Key Match Events: Brazil had 19 shots, but only three on goal.
Lucas Paqueta nearly found the opener for Brazil in the 63rd minute, but his shot hit the post.
Costa Rican defender Haxzel Quirós nearly put one in his own goal in the 72nd minute, but goalkeeper Patrick Sequeira was alert, keeping the ball out.
Sequeira was again pressed into action making another game-saving save nearly 10 minutes later.
Pre-Game Insights: Costa Rica men’s national team soccer coach Gustavo Alfaro placed all the pressure on Brazil.
Legendary midfielder Ronaldinho called this collection ‘one of the worst teams in recent years.’
Post-Match Reflections: Alfaro said after the game, ‘This result does not change where we are in this process. I’m trying to find answers in this tournament. The answers may be found in the responses of the player in this situation. Hopefully, they (the opposition) will start looking at Costa Rica with respect because they will fight until the end.’

Brazil coach Dorival Júnior said, ‘We were not able to achieve the finishing (goal-scoring). I think it was a well-contested match, unfortunately, we had some difficulties. We created great opportunities. … We have to find solutions and our worked with be directed in that sense.’

Costa Rican midfielder Ariel Lassiter said, ‘I think we always want to go out there to get three points, but I think this is a good start for us in this group. Obviously, with Colombia ahead, they’ve had I don’t know how many games without losing, so I think it’ll be a different beast in Colombia, but we’ll take this point …I think it’ll help us with our confidence to keep on going in this tournament.’
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was played at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood in front of 67,158 fans.
Costa Rica will face Colombia on Friday at State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona, and will conclude group play against Paraguay (July 2).
Brazil will face Paraguay on Friday at Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas and then concludes group stage play against Colombia (July 2).
